speaker: Teacher
text: So we've seen how, in French, final consonants are not generally pronounced, consonants written on the ends of words, and that Ns and Ms on the end of syllables aren't either. They get kind of swallowed into the nose and affect the vowel before them. This means a word can often sound quite different to how it's written, like the word for now in French, which is spelled as if it were "maintenant" but sounds like...

speaker: Teacher
text: Don't try to find it from memory, but look again at "maintenant," and use this as an opportunity to think again. Okay, what do I know about French, and how will it affect how I pronounce "maintenant"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. "Maintenant" [nasal 'in' and 'an' sounds] or "maint'nant." [nasal 'in' and 'an' sounds] So in writing, we can see the connection to "now" much better. Not the word "now", but the meaning of "now", "maintenant", like maintain, no? Maintain has a connection to now. Maintaining is all about bringing into the now, no? So this also means that if we hear a T, for example, on the end of a word which is a consonant, no, a T, so the vowel, like in "la porte," "la visite," "trente," [nasal 'a' sound] "thirty," that the word probably doesn't end in a consonant. Otherwise, we wouldn't hear it. "La porte," "la visite," "trente" [nasal 'a' sound] are all, of course, spelled with a final E. In the same way, we have, for example, "la baguette." "La baguette," spelled "B-A-G-U-E-T-T-E," just like in English. The E on the end lets us know to sound the consonant before it. "Baguette."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je veux la baguette." And "baguette" can also mean rod, like, you know, like a stick of wood or something. Wand, you know, like a magical wand. How would you say, "I want it," and we mean the baguette?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je la veux." So we saw how it was the same as the word for the. So if we mean "la baguette," we use "la" for it. "Je la veux." So we noticed that "baguette" is feminine, no? "La baguette." And as I mentioned with the "I-O-N" words, like "tradition," "collection," "célébration," which are also feminine. We have "la tradition," "la collection," no? Then we can look to the end of words to see if we found a pattern for gender, like in how we identified that the "I-O-N" words were feminine. So we have "la baguette." We also have "la cigarette," spelled like in English. "La cigarette."

speaker: Teacher
text: Which goes with "la," no? "La cigarette." And ends with "-ette" as well, "E-T-T-E," like "baguette." We have "la maisonnette." Like in English, no? "Maisonnette," like a small house. Again ending "E-T-T-E." "La bicyclette," the bicycle. So it indeed looks like we found a pattern, no, with this "E-T-T-E" ending, showing us that the word is feminine. What was "you want"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Veux-tu," or "tu veux." "Do you want the bicycle"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Veux-tu la bicyclette"? "Do you want it"? And we mean the bicycle.

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. "Tu la veux." Now, what if we mean a masculine it? If we refer to a masculine object, "do you want it"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu le veux." Very good. We can also use this masculine it, "le," for something general, like if we're referring to, you know, something happening with it. You know, "do you want it"? "Do you want it to happen," for example. Or, you know, something general, we can also use this "le." So we have learnt how the word for it goes before the verb, no, before the words like want, which comes from "to want". To words are verbs, no? "To want," "to be able," "to owe," or "to prepare." So we've seen how it comes before our verb, "tu le veux." If we want to say something like, "I want to repair it. Can you repair it?" then the it goes before the verb that's talking about it. So just as we say, "Tu le veux," when we mean "You want it," we put it before the verb that refers to it. If we say, for example, "I want to repair it," we'll say, "I want it repair," because repair refers to it, no? "I want to repair it." And we keep that it just before the verb that's talking about it. So we say, "I want it repair." "I want it to repair." So how would you say that? "I want to repair it."

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je veux le réparer." "I want to prepare it."

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je veux le préparer." How was "I must" or "I owe" related to debt in English?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je dois." Good. If you think of how it starts from debt, the rest comes easily, no? "Je d- d- je dois." And how was the car?

speaker: Teacher
text: La voiture." [uvular R sound] "I must repair the car." [uvular R sound] "I owe to repair the car." [uvular R sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je dois réparer la voiture." [uvular R sound] "I must repair it." [uvular R sound] And we mean the car still. "I must repair it." [uvular R sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je dois la réparer." [uvular R sound] How would you say "organization," "organization" in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. And what happens to "la organisation" when you put them together?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. The same thing happens with the word for "it", no, which is just the word for the, we've said. "Tu dois l'organiser." [nasal 'o' and 'a' sounds] So you had chosen "le" here, no, for "it", which could refer to organising a masculine thing like "le diner" or "le souper," the dinner or the supper.

speaker: Teacher
text: Or something without gender, something general like organising that something happens or gets sold, or something else that we're not using a word to refer to. For this, we can also use this "le." But of course, here, we don't notice if it's "le" or "la." "Tu dois l'organiser." [nasal 'o' and 'a' sounds]
